The Department of English faculty includes award-winning teachers, researchers, and mentors, and the department regularly offers a wide range of courses in literary study, film, popular culture, critical theory, linguistics, rhetoric, and composition. Our curriculum is designed to give students a broad exposure to literary history and theory while allowing them to specialize in areas of particular interest to them. In addition to our B.A. degree, we offer a minor in English and a graduate certificate in English. We encourage students interested in teaching secondary education to consider the English major in conjunction with the UNC Charlotte Cato College of Education’s graduate program in secondary English education.
ScholarshipAmount: Ranges from $1,000 to full in-state tuition and fees

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in European and Russian Studies
Description: Students pursuing the BA in Russian and Eastern European Studies (REES) undertake a cross-disciplinary investigation of the languages, history, culture, politics, and economics of this region. The program is flexible, allowing students to tailor their studies to their individual interests by choosing a track; for example, one emphasizing the Russian dimension of the region; the other emphasizing the East European dimension. With Russian as the common element, language study begins with intensive courses at Tufts, or students can transfer credits from other institutions. REES majors typically pursue a second major or minor. Many REES majors complete their language and cross-cultural requirements during a summer, semester, or year abroad in Russia or Eastern Europe. The program prepares students for a wide variety of careers including government, international business, journalism, NGOs, education, and graduate studies.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, need-based, and a combination of both.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in French
Requirements: Admission to UNC Charlotte is competitive. The review is a holistic one, taking into consideration your high school courses, the grades you’ve earned, your class rank, and your essay. Extracurricular activities and your leadership, service, and work experiences are also considered. Minimum High School Course Requirements include: 4 course units of English, 4 course units of mathematics, 3 course units of science, 2 course units of social science, and 2 additional academic courses.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in French program allows students to combine a broad liberal arts education with specialization in the French language and in the cultures of French-speaking countries around the world. Graduates are prepared for careers that require the ability to communicate across cultures in French and English and a knowledge of the cultures of the French-speaking world. A major in French can also be combined with teacher licensure. French majors are strongly encouraged to combine their studies with another major or minor.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Geography and Environment
Requirements: To apply for admission to UNC Charlotte as a first-year student, you will need to submit the following: an online application (The Common App or the Future 49er Application), an $80 non-refundable application fee, and your official high school transcript. First-year students are required to submit an essay response of 250-650 words. UNC Charlotte is test-optional for students applying for admission through fall 2024. If you choose to submit your standardized test scores (SAT or ACT), you can self-report them on your application or have them sent directly from the testing agency.
Concentration: Environmental Studies Concentration, Geographic Information Science Concentration
Description:
The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) in Geography and Environment provides students with an understanding of Earth's physical and human systems and the interconnections between them. Through their coursework, students learn how to analyze geographical phenomena at multiple scales (local to global), understand various environmental processes, analyze population and cultural patterns, develop analytical and critical thinking skills, and learn geographic techniques such as cartography, remote sensing, and Geographic Information Systems (GIS). The program offers two concentrations: Environmental Studies and Geographic Information Science.

Degree Program Objectives:

*   Examine Earth's environmental and human systems and the interactions between them.
*   Demonstrate knowledge of the methods and theories of human geography.
*   Demonstrate knowledge of the methods and theories of physical geography.
*   Demonstrate an understanding of methods and technologies used in geographic research and analysis.
*   Understand and explain patterns and processes of environmental change, particularly in the context of sustainability and social justice.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Geological Sciences – Earth Science Concentration
Requirements: Students may declare a major in Geological Sciences at any time, but they must meet with a departmental undergraduate advisor to do so.
Description: Geological Sciences is the study of the Earth's materials and processes. Geologists study natural hazards such as earthquakes, landslides, and volcanic eruptions; natural resources such as water, fossil fuels, and mineral deposits; and environmental problems such as groundwater contamination and coastal erosion. The curriculum provides students with a strong background in Earth science and prepares them for professional careers or graduate studies. The department offers two degrees: the Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Geological Sciences and the Bachelor of Science (BS) in Geological Sciences. The BA degree is recommended for students who want to combine a general background in Earth science with a broad liberal arts education, pursue a second major or minor, or are interested in careers in secondary science education, environmental law, science writing, or business. The BS degree is recommended for students who plan to pursue a professional career in geology or graduate studies in geology or a related field. Both degrees provide students with a strong background in Earth science fundamentals and quantitative skills necessary to address complex problems related to the Earth.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Germanic and Slavic Languages and Literatures – German Studies Concentration
Requirements: Admission to this major is open to any UNC Charlotte student in good academic standing with a GPA of 2.00 or better. For general university admission, in addition to your academic record, UNC Charlotte considers standardized test scores (if you choose to submit them), essay, and your extracurricular activities and what you’ve accomplished outside of the classroom.
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Germanic and Slavic Languages and Literatures provides a strong background in German language, literature, and culture, while also giving students an opportunity to study a Slavic language and culture. The German Studies Concentration offers students an in-depth study of German language, literature, and culture (including film, history, and contemporary society) while also allowing them to study Russian, a related language, and its culture. Through a strong program of study, students develop advanced German language skills, critical thinking abilities, and an appreciation for other cultures. The program prepares students for careers in fields such as business, education, government, translation, and international relations, or for continued study in graduate school. Students have the opportunity to study abroad, participate in internships, and engage in undergraduate research.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Germanic and Slavic Languages and Literatures – Russian Language and Culture Concentration
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Germanic and Slavic Languages and Literatures is a degree program designed to provide students with advanced proficiency in German or Russian, as well as a comprehensive understanding of the literature, history, and culture of the German-speaking and Russian-speaking worlds. The program aims to foster critical thinking, analytical skills, and cross-cultural competence, preparing students for careers in diverse fields such as education, international business, diplomacy, translation, and graduate studies. Students choose one of two concentrations: German Language and Culture or Russian Language and Culture. Both concentrations emphasize rigorous language training complemented by in-depth study of relevant literary, historical, and cultural topics. Through immersive coursework and opportunities for study abroad, students develop a nuanced appreciation for linguistic and cultural diversity, equipping them to engage effectively with global challenges and opportunities.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Germanic and Slavic Languages and Literatures – Slavic and East European Studies Concentration
Requirements: To apply for first-year admission, applicants must submit an online application (via the Future 49er Portal, Common App, or CFNC), a non-refundable application fee, and an official high school transcript. A personal essay is also required. UNC Charlotte is test-optional for first-year applicants for Spring 2024 and Fall 2024 terms, meaning applicants can choose whether or not to submit ACT or SAT test scores.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Concentration: Slavic and East European Studies Concentration
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Germanic and Slavic Languages and Literatures offers concentrations in German Studies, Russian Studies, and Slavic and East European Studies. All concentrations include instruction in the relevant languages, literatures, and cultures in depth, as well as an interdisciplinary exploration of the region’s history, politics, and related fields. In all concentrations, students are encouraged to participate in study abroad programs in Germany, Russia, or other relevant countries in order to achieve the necessary linguistic proficiency and cultural competency.
ScholarshipType: University-wide scholarships, college-specific scholarships, departmental scholarships, Merit scholarships

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Global Studies
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Global Studies offers students a deep and critical understanding of the forces and factors that shape the interconnected contemporary world. The program is inherently interdisciplinary, drawing on a range of humanities and social science fields to provide a comprehensive approach to global issues. Students choose one of seven concentrations, each allowing for a more in-depth study of a particular region or cross-cutting theme. In all concentrations, students will cultivate critical thinking, communication, and research skills through rigorous coursework, foreign language study, and experiential learning opportunities. All students complete a required study abroad or international internship experience, equipping them with practical intercultural skills and knowledge. The program prepares students for careers in government, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), international business, and education, as well as for graduate study in related fields.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Haitian Creole
Bachelor of Arts in Hindi-Urdu
Description: The Hindi-Urdu program at UNC Charlotte offers students the opportunity to learn modern standard Hindi and Urdu, the two most prominent languages of South Asia, and gain familiarity with the cultures of the Hindi-Urdu speaking world. These languages are grammatically very similar; the main difference is their writing systems, which are respectively Devanagari and Perso-Arabic. The Hindi-Urdu major can lead to a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) degree, while the minor can complement a major in another discipline such as political science, history, international studies, or religious studies. With around half a billion speakers, Hindi-Urdu is the fourth most commonly spoken language in the world, and there is a growing demand for trained professionals with knowledge of Hindi-Urdu in fields such as business, foreign service, education, and social work. Our program offers five levels of language training as well as courses in culture and literature, making it among the most comprehensive Hindi-Urdu programs in the southeastern United States.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in History
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in History program exposes students to a wide range of human experience and helps them develop skills fundamental to any profession requiring clear thinking and communication. The curriculum emphasizes analytical and interpretive skills; understanding of political, social, economic, and cultural change; and appreciation of diverse cultures and perspectives on the human past. The program also supports the discovery and exploration of intellectual passions that are the hallmarks of a liberally educated individual. The history curriculum is global in scope, allowing students to explore the human past in all parts of the world, from antiquity to the present. The department offers courses in U.S., European, Asian, African, Latin American, and Middle Eastern history, as well as courses in historical methodologies. Additionally, students can take advantage of numerous internship and study abroad opportunities, including the Public History Internship, which provides hands-on experience in museums, archives, and historical sites. An interdisciplinary minor in Public History is also available. Graduates of the program are well-prepared for diverse career paths, including teaching, law, public service, journalism, business, archival and museum work, or graduate study in history and related fields.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Latin American Studies
Requirements: First-year applicants must submit: an application for admission and application fee, an official high school transcript, and an essay. The submission of official SAT or ACT scores is optional for most applicants.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: Latin American Studies (LTAM) is an interdisciplinary program that investigates the history, cultures, politics, and social dynamics of Latin America and the Caribbean from the pre-colonial period to the present. The program is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the diverse societies and cultures of the region, as well as the historical and contemporary challenges and opportunities they face. Students will develop critical thinking skills, cross-cultural understanding, and proficiency in Spanish or Portuguese. Graduates of the Latin American Studies program are prepared for a wide range of careers in fields such as international relations, government, non-profit organizations, education, journalism, and business, as well as for graduate study in Latin American Studies or related disciplines.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Linguistics, Interpretation, and Translation
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Linguistics, Interpretation, and Translation (LIT) offers an interdisciplinary approach to the study of language and communication. It combines theoretical and applied linguistics, the science of interpreting and translation, and cross-cultural communication to prepare students for careers in diverse professional fields. The program emphasizes global literacy, critical thinking, and effective communication, equipping graduates with the skills necessary to navigate complex linguistic and cultural landscapes. Through rigorous coursework, practical training, and experiential learning opportunities, students develop proficiency in at least one foreign language (Spanish, German, French, or Japanese), gain a deep understanding of linguistic structures, acquire interpreting and translation techniques, and cultivate an appreciation for linguistic and cultural diversity. The program is designed to provide a solid foundation for those interested in pursuing graduate studies in linguistics, interpreting, translation, or related fields, as well as for those seeking immediate employment in areas such as diplomacy, international business, healthcare, legal services, community outreach, and education.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Media and Journalism
Concentration: Digital Video and Film, Journalism, Public Relations, Sports Communication
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Media and Journalism provides students with a strong liberal arts education and professional training for careers in a wide array of media and media-related fields, including journalism, public relations, digital media production, sports communication, and advertising. Graduates are prepared for positions in news organizations (print, broadcast, and online), public relations and strategic communication firms, corporate communication departments, advertising agencies, production companies, and other media-focused enterprises. Students develop critical thinking skills, ethical decision-making abilities, and professional competencies in areas such as writing, editing, visual storytelling, multimedia production, strategic communication planning, and media analytics.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, financial need, or other criteria

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Music
Requirements: Admission to the Department of Music is a two-part process. First, students must apply for admission to the University through the UNC Charlotte Undergraduate Admissions Office. Second, students must complete an online Music Application and a performance audition on a primary instrument or voice. Auditions are held on campus on specific dates (see music.charlotte.edu for details). Admission to the University does not guarantee admission to the Department of Music. Music majors must successfully pass a performance audition to be accepted into the program.
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Music (BA) is designed for students seeking a broad education in music within a liberal arts context. This degree allows students to pursue their interests in music while also exploring other academic disciplines. The program provides a strong foundation in music theory, history, and performance, preparing students for diverse careers in music, further graduate study, or a range of professions that value critical thinking, creativity, and interdisciplinary understanding.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Music History and Literature
Description: The Music History & Literature Concentration is for students who want to explore music through a humanities-based approach. It emphasizes the study of music history, theory, and cultural contexts, preparing students for graduate study, careers in arts administration, or other fields requiring strong research and writing skills.
Accredidation: The Department of Music is an accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Music (NASM).
ScholarshipAmount: Awards range from $1,000 to $4,000 per year

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in North American Studies
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in North American Studies explores the cultures, societies, and histories of Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean, and the United States, as well as the connections among them. The program emphasizes global and transnational approaches to understanding North America, providing students with critical tools to engage with the region’s diverse peoples, experiences, and contexts. The program offers an interdisciplinary approach to North American Studies, drawing on courses from a range of fields, including Africana Studies, Anthropology, Communication Studies, Criminal Justice, English, Geography and Earth Sciences, Global Studies, History, Languages and Culture Studies, Latin American Studies, Political Science, Psychology, Religious Studies, Sociology, and Women's and Gender Studies. The program offers students an opportunity to learn about North America in historical and contemporary contexts, preparing them for careers in government, journalism, education, NGOs, and the private sector. The program also offers students the opportunity to conduct original research on a topic of their choice and to engage with community partners through internships and other experiential learning opportunities.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Peace, War, and Defense
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Peace, War, and Defense provides students with an interdisciplinary understanding of the causes of war and peace. Students learn about the role of diplomacy, international law, and conflict resolution in preventing and resolving conflicts, as well as the history, theory, and practice of warfare. The program also examines the social, political, economic, and cultural factors that contribute to conflict and cooperation between states and non-state actors. Students in the program develop critical thinking, analytical, and communication skills necessary for careers in government, non-governmental organizations, international organizations, and the private sector, as well as for graduate study in related fields. The program is housed in the Department of Political Science and Public Administration.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy
Description: Philosophy provides an excellent liberal arts education by developing critical thinking, argumentative, analytical, and writing skills. These skills are highly valued by employers, graduate programs, and professional schools. Students in the Philosophy B.A. program study topics in ethics, logic, metaphysics, epistemology, social and political philosophy, aesthetics, and the history of philosophy, among others. Students will learn to analyze complex concepts, evaluate arguments, and construct well-reasoned positions on fundamental questions.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Political Science
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Political Science is designed for students interested in studying the theory and practice of government and politics. This program examines political ideas, institutions, policies, and behavior, both domestically and internationally. Students will develop critical thinking skills, research abilities, and a deep understanding of political systems, preparing them for careers in government, non-profit organizations, law, journalism, business, or for further graduate study.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Public Policy Analysis
Description: The Public Policy Analysis, B.A. is an interdisciplinary program designed to prepare students for careers in public, private, and non-profit organizations that focus on the analysis, development, and implementation of public policies. Students will gain a strong foundation in economic, political, and social theories, as well as quantitative and qualitative research methods essential for effective policy analysis. The program emphasizes critical thinking, ethical decision-making, and communication skills necessary to address complex societal challenges. Graduates will be equipped to evaluate policy alternatives, contribute to evidence-based policy making, and advocate for policy changes that promote social welfare.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Religious Studies
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) in Religious Studies is designed to expose students to a variety of religious traditions, regions, and theoretical approaches. Students will develop critical thinking and analytical skills, as well as an understanding of the diversity of human cultures and beliefs. Our graduates are well-prepared for careers in fields such as education, journalism, public service, and non-profit organizations, as well as for further graduate study in religious studies or related disciplines. The B.A. program in Religious Studies provides students with an academic and non-sectarian approach to understanding the diverse roles of religion in human cultures, both past and present. Through rigorous coursework, students develop a range of valuable skills, including critical thinking, analytical reasoning, research, and written and oral communication. These skills are highly valued by employers in a wide array of fields and provide excellent preparation for graduate study in a variety of disciplines.
CostPerCredit: In-State: $145.50/credit hour (tuition only); Out-of-State: $731.50/credit hour (tuition only) (based on 2023-2024 rates)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Sociology
Description: Sociology is the scientific study of human social life. This includes examining the social causes and consequences of human behavior, social relationships, and social organization. Sociologists study virtually every aspect of human society: the family; racial, ethnic, and gender relations; social class; crime and deviance; social movements; health and illness; education; religion; law; politics; and organizations. A Bachelor of Arts degree in Sociology provides students with knowledge of social theory and various research methods. This background prepares students for graduate study in Sociology, Law, Public Health, Urban Planning, Business, and other fields. It also provides an excellent foundation for a variety of careers in government, education, non-profit organizations, and business. Sociology majors develop marketable skills, including critical thinking, problem solving, teamwork, data analysis, and communication. The Sociology program at UNC Charlotte offers three concentrations: Applied Sociology; Crime and Justice; and Medical Sociology. The Applied Sociology concentration prepares students for careers in the private and public sector that require program planning and evaluation skills, as well as a more general understanding of social issues. The Crime and Justice concentration provides students with knowledge and skills related to criminology, deviance, and law within a social context. The Medical Sociology concentration prepares students for careers in health-related organizations and graduate training in health professions, public health, or medical sociology.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Spanish
Requirements: Admission decisions for first-year students are based on a combination of: High school course selection and academic rigor, Performance in coursework (unweighted GPA), Standardized test scores (SAT or ACT), if submitted, Essay and letters of recommendation, if submitted.
Description:
The Bachelor of Arts in Spanish is a program for students seeking an in-depth study of the Spanish language, Hispanic literatures, and cultures from across the globe. Students complete 42 credit hours above the 2000-level, including a minimum of 24 credit hours at the 3000-level and above and a minimum of 15 credit hours at the 4000-level. All students completing a B.A. in Spanish must participate in an approved study abroad program.

Learning Outcomes:
Upon completion of the program, students should be able to:
*   Interpret and analyze complex materials in Spanish
*   Express complex ideas orally in Spanish
*   Express complex ideas in writing in Spanish
*   Analyze and evaluate literary and cultural texts
*   Employ knowledge of the linguistic components of the Spanish language
*   Communicate effectively with members of Hispanic communities
*   Demonstrate cultural competence in the Hispanic world
*   Evaluate language learning strategies and apply them effectively

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Studio Arts
Requirements: First-Year applicants are required to submit the following items for their application to be considered complete: Online Application, Official high school transcript, Official college transcripts (if applicable), $80 application fee or approved fee waiver. The following items are optional: Standardized test scores, Essay, List of activities/accomplishments.
Description: The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) in Art degree is a liberal arts program, offering students the flexibility to pursue a double major or a minor in another discipline while completing an undergraduate degree in the visual arts. The B.A. program requires 39 credit hours in Art (including Art History). Students pursuing the B.A. in Art may not declare a concentration. Graduates with a B.A. in Art pursue a range of careers or graduate school opportunities including teaching, arts administration, museum and gallery work, or other professions in creative industries. The B.A. in Art offers general education courses as well as intermediate and advanced courses in a variety of visual art areas and art history, allowing students to explore the visual arts in a variety of mediums and forms.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Visual Arts
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Art provides students with a broad exposure to the visual arts and art history while providing a foundation in fundamental art processes and theories. Students select one concentration from the following options: Art History, Art Therapy, Community Arts, Digital Media, Drawing, Fibers, Graphic Design, Illustration, Painting, Photography, Print Media, Sculpture. This program allows students to combine their art studies with an additional major or minor in another academic discipline. The B.A. degree provides students with opportunities to develop their intellectual, aesthetic, and creative potential while preparing them for careers in fields where a flexible education, critical thinking, and visual communication skills are important. Graduates are prepared for careers in fields such as art and gallery management, art administration, public relations, visual communication, arts education, and arts programming, or for graduate studies in a range of art and humanities disciplines. Graduates of the Art (B.A.) may also apply to graduate programs for careers in counseling, art therapy, public health and other related fields that utilize visual art making within a therapeutic, community-based or arts integrated context.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Arts in Women's Studies
Requirements:
To be considered for admission, first-year applicants must submit the following:

1. Online Application: The Common App or the Future 49er Application
2. $80 non-refundable application fee
3. Official high school transcript
4. Official college transcript(s), if applicable (for any dual-enrollment courses taken)
5. Standardized test scores (SAT or ACT). Please note: UNC Charlotte will be test-optional for students applying for admission through Fall 2024.

In addition to your application, we review your high school transcript to ensure you’ve completed the Minimum Course Requirements (MCR) set by the UNC Board of Governors:

- Four course units in English
- Four course units in mathematics (including algebra I, geometry, algebra II, and a fourth math course with algebra II as a prerequisite)
- Three course units in science (including a life science, a physical science, and a laboratory course)
- Two course units in social studies (including one unit in U.S. history)
- Two additional academic courses from English, mathematics, science, social studies, world languages, or computer science.
CostPerCredit: NC Resident: $184.25/Credit Hour (Tuition only); Non-Resident: $760.75/Credit Hour (Tuition only)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Applied Sciences
Bachelor of Science in Astronomy
Requirements: To apply as a first-year student, you will need to submit the following: Online Application, $80 Application Fee, Official High School Transcript, SAT or ACT Scores (Optional for 2024 applicants), Essay (Required), Recommendation Letters (Optional).
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Astronomy degree program at UNC Charlotte focuses on the quantitative study of the universe beyond the Earth. The curriculum provides students with a broad background in physics and mathematics, along with specialized coursework in astronomy and astrophysics. Students develop a fundamental understanding of astronomical phenomena, observational techniques, and theoretical models. The program prepares students for graduate studies in astronomy, astrophysics, or related fields, as well as for careers in science education, planetariums, observatories, and technical industries requiring strong analytical and problem-solving skills.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Bioinformatics
Department: College of Computing and Informatics, College of Liberal Arts & Sciences

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Biology
CostPerCredit: NC Resident: $708.67/Credit Hour; Non-NC Resident: $1,976.83/Credit Hour
ScholarshipAmount: Varies by award (e.g., $500, up to $1,000 for departmental scholarships)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Biomedical Engineering
Department: The William States Lee College of Engineering
Description: The Mechanical Engineering Department offers a Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering (B.S.M.E.) with a concentration in Biomedical Engineering. This concentration focuses on the application of mechanical engineering principles to the design and development of medical devices, instrumentation, and systems. Students in the Biomedical Engineering Concentration will gain a strong foundation in mechanical engineering fundamentals, along with specialized knowledge in areas such as biomechanics, biomaterials, medical imaging, and physiological systems. The curriculum is designed to prepare students for careers in the biomedical industry, medical research, or for further graduate studies in biomedical engineering or related fields.
Accredidation: The Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering (B.S.M.E.) program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Business Administration
Requirements: Admission to the Bachelor of Science in Business Administration program is handled through general undergraduate admissions to UNC Charlotte. Required Application Materials include an online application, application fee, and official high school transcript (and college transcripts if applicable). Recommended Items include a personal essay, 2-3 letters of recommendation, and a list of extracurricular activities. Standardized testing (SAT/ACT) is optional for first-year applicants through Fall 2024.
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Business Administration (BSBA) degree provides students with a broad knowledge of business and a deeper understanding in a specific concentration field of business. The BSBA degree is designed to prepare students for a variety of entry-level professional positions and to provide a foundation for graduate study. Graduates are highly sought after by employers for their business acumen and problem-solving abilities.
Accredidation: The Belk College of Business is accredited by AACSB International, the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business. AACSB Accreditation is the hallmark of excellence in business education, and has been earned by less than five percent of the world's business programs.
CostPerCredit: NC Resident: $183.79/credit hour (tuition only); Non-NC Resident: $838.96/credit hour (tuition only). Additional fees apply. Plus a differential tuition of $80 per credit hour for upper-division business courses.
CollegeApplicationFee: In-state: $7,861/year; Out-of-state: $23,585/year (includes full-time tuition and mandatory fees). A differential tuition of $80 per credit hour is charged for upper-division business courses.
ScholarshipType: Based on academic major, GPA, financial need, and campus/community involvement.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Chemistry
Description: Chemistry is the study of matter and its transformations. The curriculum for the Bachelor of Science (B.S.) degree is designed to prepare students for careers in chemistry and related fields, for graduate study in chemistry, or for professional study such as medicine, dentistry, or veterinary science. Students majoring in Chemistry take a strong fundamental sequence of courses in general, analytical, organic, inorganic, and physical chemistry, as well as a required capstone course. Students also take courses in mathematics and physics. The B.S. in Chemistry requires 120 credit hours.
Accredidation: Approved by the American Chemical Society (ACS)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Chemistry – Biochemistry Track
Description: A Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Chemistry provides a solid foundation for students interested in a variety of careers in chemistry, biochemistry, and related fields such as medicine, dentistry, pharmacy, and secondary education. The comprehensive curriculum prepares students for entry-level positions in diverse chemical industries and government laboratories, as well as graduate study in various areas of chemistry and biochemistry. Students will learn the fundamental principles of chemistry through lectures, recitations, and hands-on laboratory experiences. Specific learning objectives include: Ability to apply basic chemical principles to solve problems. Ability to design and safely conduct chemical experiments. Ability to analyze and interpret chemical data. Ability to communicate scientific information effectively. Awareness of the ethical and societal implications of chemistry. The B.S. in Chemistry degree can be tailored to individual student interests through several tracks including Biochemistry, Professional, ACS Certified Professional, Chemistry Education, and Standard. All tracks include significant laboratory experience in analytical, organic, inorganic, and physical chemistry. The Professional and ACS Certified Professional tracks offer an even more rigorous curriculum with additional advanced coursework and research opportunities, making them ideal for students planning to pursue graduate studies or research careers. The Chemistry Education track prepares students for teaching chemistry at the high school level. The Biochemistry track is designed for students interested in the chemical aspects of biological systems, preparing them for careers in biotechnology, health professions, or graduate studies in biochemistry. The Standard track provides a flexible curriculum suitable for a broad range of career paths.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies. Departmental scholarships of ~$1,000 are available. University-level scholarships can cover full tuition and fees.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Chemistry – Polymer Track
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Chemistry with a Polymer Concentration is designed for students interested in careers in the polymer and materials industry. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in chemistry with a focus on polymer science through coursework in polymer chemistry, polymer physics, and polymer characterization. Students also gain hands-on experience through laboratory courses and research opportunities. Graduates of this program are well-prepared for entry-level positions in research and development, quality control, technical sales, and manufacturing in the polymer industry, as well as for graduate studies in polymer science, materials science, or related fields.
CostPerCredit: NC Resident: $317.63/Credit Hour; Non-NC Resident: $878.29/Credit Hour

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Clinical Laboratory Science
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Clinical Laboratory Science (BSCLS) program at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill is a full-time, professional, upper-division program for individuals interested in a challenging and rewarding career in health care. Clinical laboratory scientists (medical technologists) perform and supervise the performance of diagnostic laboratory tests. These laboratory professionals are critical members of the health care team who provide the data used in the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of disease. The UNC BSCLS program is one of the oldest and most respected programs in the country. Our Mission: The mission of the UNC Bachelor of Science in Clinical Laboratory Science program is to prepare highly competent and compassionate clinical laboratory scientists to serve the health care needs of North Carolina and the nation. This mission is accomplished by providing students with a comprehensive and interdisciplinary education in the basic and applied clinical laboratory sciences through didactic instruction, laboratory experience, clinical rotations, and research opportunities. We also seek to advance the profession through scholarship and service. Our Vision: The UNC Bachelor of Science in Clinical Laboratory Science program will be a national leader in clinical laboratory science education, research, and service. We will be recognized for our innovative curriculum, our commitment to student success, and our contributions to the advancement of the clinical laboratory science profession.
Accredidation: The UNC Bachelor of Science in Clinical Laboratory Science program is accredited by the National Accrediting Agency for Clinical Laboratory Sciences (NAACLS), 5600 N River Rd, Suite 720, Rosemont, IL 60018-5119; (773) 714-8880.
CostPerCredit: NC Resident: $292.46/credit hour; Non-Resident: $1,538.38/credit hour (based on 2023-2024 rates)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Computational and Applied Mathematics
Requirements: To determine admissibility, UNC Charlotte conducts a comprehensive review of the application and credentials. Factors considered include: high school coursework and rigor, cumulative unweighted high school GPA, standardized test scores (SAT or ACT) if submitted, the application essay, and extracurricular activities and work experience.
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Computational and Applied Mathematics is an interdisciplinary degree that provides students with strong computational skills in mathematics, statistics, and computer science and an understanding of how to apply them to real-world problems. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in core mathematics, including calculus, linear algebra, and differential equations, along with a significant emphasis on computational methods, numerical analysis, mathematical modeling, and statistical analysis. Students will develop problem-solving abilities and learn to implement computational solutions using programming languages like Python, R, and MATLAB. Graduates will be well-prepared for careers in data science, quantitative analysis, actuarial science, scientific computing, and various fields requiring strong analytical and computational skills, as well as for graduate studies in applied mathematics, statistics, and related disciplines.
CostPerCredit: NC Resident: $311.68/credit hour; Non-NC Resident: $905.51/credit hour

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science
Requirements: First-year applicants are evaluated based on their weighted high school GPA and the rigor of their high school coursework. Minimum course requirements include: 4 units of English, 4 units of Mathematics (including a course beyond Algebra II), 3 units of Science (including one life science, one physical science, and one lab), 2 units of Social Science (including one U.S. History). Two units of a second language are also recommended.
Description:
The Bachelor of Science in Computer Science program at UNC Charlotte prepares students for careers in the rapidly growing field of computer science. Students in the program develop a strong foundation in computer science theory and practice, including programming, data structures, algorithms, operating systems, and computer architecture. The curriculum emphasizes problem-solving, critical thinking, and communication skills, preparing graduates to excel in diverse roles such as software developers, data scientists, cybersecurity analysts, and AI/machine learning engineers.

The program offers a flexible curriculum with optional concentrations, allowing students to specialize in areas of particular interest. Graduates of the program are well-prepared for a variety of roles in industry, government, and academia, as well as for further graduate study. Career opportunities for computer science graduates are vast and include positions such as software engineer, web developer, mobile app developer, data analyst, cybersecurity specialist, and machine learning engineer.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Earth and Marine Sciences
Requirements: UNC Charlotte requires a minimum of 16 high school units for admission: 4 units in English, 4 units in Math (including algebra I, geometry, algebra II, and a fourth level math course beyond algebra II), 3 units in Science (including a life science, a physical science, and a science with a lab), 2 units in Social Science (including one U.S. history course), and 2 units in a second language.
Concentration: Earth Science Specialization, Marine Science Specialization
Description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Earth and Marine Sciences is designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of the Earth system, encompassing its geological, hydrological, atmospheric, and biological components, with a strong emphasis on marine environments. Students will develop a robust scientific foundation through a curriculum that integrates classroom instruction, laboratory exercises, and field experiences. The program prepares graduates for diverse career paths in environmental consulting, natural resource management, geological and oceanographic research, government agencies, and education, or for advanced studies in Earth and marine sciences and related fields. Emphasis is placed on critical thinking, problem-solving, and the application of scientific methods to address complex environmental and societal challenges.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Environmental Health Science
Requirements: To be considered for admission as a first-year student, applicants must submit an online application, a non-refundable application fee, and an official high school transcript. The essay is a required component of the admissions application. UNC Charlotte is test-optional for first-year applicants through Fall 2024, meaning applicants may choose whether or not to submit SAT or ACT scores.
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: Public health is the science of protecting and improving the health of people and their communities. Public health professionals work to prevent people from getting sick or injured and promote wellness by encouraging healthy behaviors across entire populations. They promote healthcare equity, accessibility, and quality, and work to eliminate disparities and improve the health of vulnerable populations. The Bachelor of Science in Public Health (BSPH) is a competitive program that provides students with the foundational knowledge and skills to address public health issues. The BSPH prepares graduates for a wide array of career options in governmental, non-profit, and private organizations, and for graduate study in public health and other related fields. Students select one of two concentrations: Community Health or Environmental Health Science. Both concentrations are built on a core public health curriculum that addresses the science of public health and population-level health improvement. Students complete a practicum experience, which provides hands-on public health experience in an agency or organization under the supervision of a public health professional. The BSPH is accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health (CEPH).
Accredidation: Accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health (CEPH)
CostPerCredit: In-State: $309.21/credit hour; Out-of-State: $952.80/credit hour (Total Tuition and Fees for 2023-2024)
CollegeApplicationFee: In-State: $7,419/year, Out-of-State: $22,865/year (Total Tuition and Fees for 2023-2024)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Environmental Science
Description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Earth and Environmental Sciences program offers three concentrations: Earth Science, Environmental Science, and Geology. This curriculum prepares students for employment in a variety of scientific fields with federal, state, and local agencies, environmental and geotechnical consulting firms, and industry, as well as for graduate study. Students gain a fundamental understanding of Earth and environmental processes and learn to apply scientific and technological principles to complex societal and environmental problems. Emphasis is placed on quantitative and field skills needed by earth and environmental science professionals. All concentrations share a common core curriculum, providing students with broad training in the earth and environmental sciences and with a strong foundation in mathematics, physics, and chemistry. Upper-division coursework offers students the opportunity to specialize in one of the three concentration areas. The Environmental Science concentration is for students interested in environmental issues from a natural science perspective. Coursework focuses on the study of interactions between physical, chemical, and biological components of the Earth's environment, and on human impacts on the environment, including water and air pollution, waste management, and sustainable energy development.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Information Science
CostPerCredit: In-state: $158.83/credit hour; Out-of-state: $793.71/credit hour (2024-2025 Undergraduate Tuition)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Mathematics
Requirements: Admission to this major is competitive. Meeting the minimum requirements does not guarantee admission. Students must have a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.0. Students must meet the progression requirements of the department.
Description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Mathematics provides a foundation in theoretical and applied mathematics and is an excellent choice for students interested in graduate school in mathematics or a mathematics-related field, or for those interested in careers requiring a strong background in mathematics. The B.S. in Mathematics is a flexible degree with several concentrations for students with a wide variety of interests and career goals. Students choose a concentration in Actuarial Mathematics, Applied Mathematics, Business, Data Science, General Mathematics, or Pure Mathematics. The concentration taken is listed on the student's academic transcript. The Department of Mathematics and Statistics offers many opportunities for students to engage in research with faculty. Students are encouraged to pursue such opportunities to enhance their undergraduate experience and prepare for graduate school or careers. The department also encourages all students to complete an internship to gain valuable work experience in a mathematics-related field. For students seeking licensure to teach secondary mathematics, a Master of Arts in Teaching (M.A.T.) with a concentration in Secondary Mathematics Education is also available through The Cato College of Education.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Neuroscience and Neurobiology
Requirements: First-year admission to UNC Charlotte is competitive. Our review is a holistic one, taking into consideration your high school courses, grades in those courses, your class standing and your test scores, if you choose to submit them. Required Application Materials: Online Application, Non-refundable $80 application fee, Official high school transcript, Official SAT or ACT scores (optional for 2024).
Description: The Neuroscience and Neurobiology B.S. program is an interdisciplinary major developed to prepare students for careers in research or healthcare or for entrance into professional or graduate school programs that require a strong background in neuroscience. Students will learn about the structure and function of the brain and nervous system through an interdisciplinary curriculum that integrates aspects of biology, chemistry, computer science, and psychology. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in science through coursework, hands-on lab experiences, and opportunities for undergraduate research. Graduates of the program will have gained strong critical thinking, quantitative, and communication skills applicable to a broad range of careers.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Nursing
Requirements: Admission to the upper division of the Nursing major is a competitive process. Students must first be admitted to the University as a Pre-Nursing (PRNU) student. To be considered for admission to the upper division, students must submit a supplemental application to the School of Nursing. These applications are accepted twice a year. Admission is determined by several factors including, but not limited to: 1. Cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher. 2. A grade of C or better in all nursing prerequisite courses. 3. Completion of the Test of Essential Academic Skills (TEAS). 4. Other factors as determined by the School of Nursing Admission Committee. 5. Acceptance to upper division requires passing a Certified Background Check and Drug Screen. 6. Students with two failures in the same nursing prerequisite science course are not eligible to apply to the nursing program.
Fees: In-State: $4,812 per term; Out-of-State: $11,417 per term (based on 2023-2024 rates, includes a $1,000/term program fee for Upper-Division Nursing)
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) program is designed to prepare nurses who will promote, restore, and maintain health for individuals, families, groups, and communities across the life span within a variety of health care settings. The program builds upon a strong liberal arts and science background that contributes to a comprehensive professional education in nursing. Upon successful completion of the program, graduates are eligible to apply to take the National Council Licensure Examination for Registered Nurses (NCLEX-RN).
Accredidation: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing at The University of North Carolina at Charlotte is accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (http://www.ccneaccreditation.org).
CostPerCredit: In-State: $317.67 per credit hour; Out-of-State: $868.08 per credit hour (based on 2023-2024 rates)
CollegeApplicationFee: In-State: $4,812 per term; Out-of-State: $11,417 per term (based on 2023-2024 rates, includes a $1,000/term program fee for Upper-Division Nursing)

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Physical Education Teaching and Coaching
Requirements:
To be admitted into the Health and Physical Education Teacher Education Program, students must meet the following criteria:

Completion of at least 24 earned semester hours.
A cumulative GPA of at least 2.75.
A passing score on the Praxis Core Academic Skills for Educators test, or an equivalent score on the SAT or ACT.
Admission to the Teacher Education Program is a prerequisite for all upper-division KNES coursework.
Students must also maintain a grade of C or above in all major and concentration courses.
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Physical Education Teaching and Coaching prepares students to obtain teaching licenses in North Carolina, or other states through reciprocity agreements, to teach physical education in public or private schools, and to coach sport at the youth, secondary, and collegiate levels. Students will be exposed to extensive practical experiences in K-12 public school settings, including a full-time student teaching experience. Students will study curriculum development, instructional strategies, technology integration, behavior management, assessment, and adapted physical education, as well as topics in exercise science, motor development, and sport pedagogy. The rigorous coursework and field experiences will provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary for success as highly effective educators and coaches.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Physics
Description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Physics is designed for students who are interested in careers in physics or related fields, or who intend to pursue graduate study in physics. This rigorous curriculum provides a strong foundation in theoretical and experimental physics, mathematics, and related sciences. Students develop critical thinking, problem-solving, and analytical skills, preparing them for diverse professional paths or advanced academic pursuits. The program also offers opportunities for students to engage in research with faculty members, participate in internships, and join student organizations, further enhancing their educational experience and career readiness.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Public Health in Community and Global Public Health
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Public Health (BSPH) is designed to provide students with a strong foundation in public health at the undergraduate level. The curriculum provides students with knowledge, skills and abilities in the core public health areas of biostatistics, epidemiology, environmental health, health policy and management, and social and behavioral sciences. Students learn to apply evidence-based approaches to identify and assess the health needs of diverse populations, and design, implement, and evaluate health promotion and disease prevention programs. The BSPH degree is a practitioner-oriented program of study that prepares students for entry-level public health positions in a variety of governmental and non-governmental settings (e.g., local health departments, community health agencies, non-profit organizations) or for advanced study in public health or other health-related fields. The BSPH requires a minimum of 120 credit hours for graduation.

ProgramName: Bachelor of Science in Statistics
Requirements: Admission requirements for this program are the same as the general undergraduate admission requirements. First-year applicants are assessed based on high school GPA, the rigor of their high school coursework, and SAT or ACT scores (if submitted). Minimum high school course requirements include: 4 units of English; 4 units of mathematics (including Algebra I, Geometry, Algebra II, and a fourth level math course beyond Algebra II); 3 units of science (one life science, one physical science, and one lab); 2 units of social science (including one U.S. History); and 2 additional academic units from specified fields.
Description: Mathematics is a broad discipline that is integral to virtually every academic field, as well as a range of professions. Our program introduces students to the core ideas and critical applications of mathematics. Through this program, students develop problem-solving and critical-thinking skills and learn to apply mathematics in various fields. The B.S. in Mathematics offers several concentrations. The Statistics concentration is designed to provide students with a solid foundation in the theory and application of statistics. Students will learn data analysis, statistical modeling, probability theory, and statistical inference. This concentration prepares students for careers in fields such as data science, actuarial science, and biostatistics, as well as for graduate studies in statistics or related fields.
ScholarshipAmount: Merit awards for first-year students range from $3,000/year to full-ride scholarships.

ProgramName: Minor in Aerospace Studies
Description:
The Department of Aerospace Studies provides an opportunity for students to complement their degree with an Aerospace Studies minor. The Aerospace Studies minor is available to any student on campus, including students enrolled in Air Force ROTC. The minor requires a minimum of 15 credit hours of Aerospace Studies courses (AERO prefix courses), 9 of which must be at the 3000-level or above.
The minor is designed for students interested in learning more about the United States Air Force and Space Force and their roles in national defense, leadership, ethics, and communication. It provides a foundation for students interested in military service or careers in defense-related industries.

ProgramName: Minor in African American and Diaspora Studies
Requirements: The Minor in African American and Diaspora Studies requires 18 credit hours of coursework. Students must have a cumulative GPA of at least 2.0 to declare the minor.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The minor in African American and Diaspora Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to introduce students to the histories, cultures, and intellectual traditions of people of African descent. Students will engage critical questions related to race, identity, gender, sexuality, class, and nation in the context of the United States and the wider African Diaspora. The minor will offer students analytical and theoretical frameworks for understanding the varied experiences of Black people, while also fostering an appreciation for their diverse contributions to human civilization.

ProgramName: Minor in African Studies
Requirements: To declare a minor in Africana Studies, students should see the Africana Studies undergraduate coordinator. The Africana Studies minor consists of 18 credit hours. Students must complete all coursework for the minor with a grade of C or above.
Description:
The African Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give undergraduate students a broad understanding of the African continent and its diverse peoples, cultures, and institutions. The program helps students develop analytical tools to understand the historical and contemporary challenges facing African societies and their relationships with the global community.
Students who pursue the minor will take courses across disciplines, including Anthropology, Art and Art History, Communication Studies, Dance, English, History, Languages and Culture Studies, Music, Political Science and International Studies, Religious Studies, and Sociology.
The minor requires 18 credit hours, including a 3-credit core course and 15 credit hours of electives from an approved list of courses. At least nine of the 15 elective credits must be at the 3000-level or above. Students must maintain a minimum GPA of 2.0 in courses counted toward the minor. For more information, please contact Dr. Dylan Craig, Director of the African Studies minor.

ProgramName: Minor in American Indian and Indigenous Studies
Requirements: To declare a minor, a student must be in good academic standing (2.0 GPA) and complete a Change of Major/Minor form with their major advisor or in the college that houses their major.
Description: The American Indian and Indigenous Studies (AIIS) Minor at UNC Charlotte is an interdisciplinary minor designed to provide students with a foundational knowledge of the diverse cultures, histories, literatures, social issues, and political sovereignty of Indigenous peoples across the Americas. The minor offers students the opportunity to learn from multiple perspectives (humanities, social sciences, health, education, arts, and languages) and to engage in critical analysis and thoughtful discussions regarding topics such as tribal sovereignty, cultural revitalization, environmental justice, health disparities, and the ongoing impacts of colonialism. The AIIS minor prepares students to engage effectively and ethically with Indigenous communities and to advocate for social justice in diverse professional fields and graduate programs. It complements a wide range of majors including, but not limited to, Anthropology, Communication Studies, Criminal Justice, Education, English, History, International Studies, Political Science, Public Health, Psychology, Social Work, Sociology, and Women’s and Gender Studies.

ProgramName: Minor in American Studies
Requirements: Undergraduate students in good academic standing are eligible to apply.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The American Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a broad understanding of the United States. Through the minor, students learn to critically analyze the many dimensions of American culture, including its history, literature, arts, and social movements. Students learn to use different disciplinary approaches (from fields such as history, English, political science, sociology, religious studies, and art history) to examine American life. The minor encourages students to consider the complexity of American culture, its diversity, and its place in the world. The American Studies minor helps students to develop skills in critical thinking, research, and communication, which are valuable in a wide range of careers.

ProgramName: Minor in Anthropology
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Anthropology minor provides students with a broad background in the subfields of cultural anthropology, archaeology, biological anthropology, and linguistic anthropology. An anthropology minor offers students an understanding of human diversity across time and space. The minor consists of 18 credit hours of anthropology courses, including 6 credits of core courses and 12 credits of electives. The minor is appropriate for students in any major, as anthropology courses complement a wide range of academic interests. For example, students interested in international relations, human health, social justice, or cultural heritage could benefit greatly from the coursework in this minor.

ProgramName: Minor in Applied Sciences and Engineering
Department: The William States Lee College of Engineering
Description: The Applied Sciences and Engineering Minor provides an interdisciplinary program of study open to students from all colleges. The Minor provides opportunities for students to learn how to apply the scientific method and engineering principles to solve real-world problems. The coursework and project-based learning experiences are designed to enhance students’ critical thinking skills, problem-solving abilities, creativity, innovation, and teamwork. Students who complete the Minor will be well-prepared for a variety of careers in industry, government, and academia, as well as for further graduate study in science and engineering.

ProgramName: Minor in Arabic
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in Arabic Studies focuses on the language, literature, and culture of the Arab world. The program also provides insights into the religions and societies of Arabic-speaking people and addresses current issues and challenges in the Arab world. Students completing the Minor in Arabic Studies will be able to demonstrate: Proficiency in Arabic language at an intermediate level, Knowledge of the history, societies, and cultures of Arabic-speaking people, Understanding of Arab literature and intellectual traditions.

ProgramName: Minor in Archaeology
Requirements: Students can declare the Minor in Archaeology at any time. Students should declare the minor as early as possible in order to receive proper advising. To declare the minor, students should contact the program coordinator.
Description: Archaeology is the study of human societies through material culture, focusing on societies and their interactions across time and space. The interdisciplinary minor in Archaeology introduces students to the principles, methods, and theories of archaeology while providing them with a historical and comparative understanding of the material record of human cultural adaptation. The minor examines major trends in world archaeology, from the beginnings of human culture to the more recent past. A variety of courses are offered, ranging from Old World archaeology (e.g., Egyptian, Near Eastern, Greek and Roman) to New World archaeology (e.g., North, Middle, and South America). The minor also provides courses on the history of archaeology, archaeological methods, and archaeological theory. Students are encouraged to develop their interests through electives and experiential learning in the field or laboratory.

ProgramName: Minor in Art History
Requirements: Students who wish to declare a Minor in Art History must have a GPA of at least 2.0. The minor is declared online.
Description: The Minor in Art History offers an opportunity for students in any discipline to engage with the study of art, architecture, and visual culture from a global perspective. Courses focus on the analysis of visual objects, the historical contexts in which they were created, and the various ways they have been interpreted throughout history. Minors will learn research methods and theoretical approaches used in the discipline of art history while honing their skills in visual analysis, critical thinking, and written and oral communication. The minor offers flexibility for students to explore a range of art historical periods and geographies while developing a focused area of interest. Students may opt to complete an internship to gain practical experience in the field.

ProgramName: Minor in Asian Studies
Requirements: Students who wish to declare a minor in Asian Studies must meet with the program director. Students must have a minimum GPA of 2.0.
Description: The minor in Asian Studies is a sixteen (16) credit hour interdisciplinary program in Asian cultures and civilizations. The minor is sponsored by the Department of Global Studies with contributing faculty from Anthropology, Art and Art History, Dance, Geography and Earth Sciences, History, Languages and Culture Studies, and Political Science and International Studies. The minor provides students with a broad and interdisciplinary understanding of Asian cultures, history, and current events. Through its interdisciplinary approach, the minor enables students to appreciate the richness and diversity of Asian cultures from a variety of perspectives. It provides training for employment in federal, state, and local governments, international organizations, and multinational corporations and prepares students for graduate studies in international affairs.

ProgramName: Minor in Baccalaureate Education in Science and Teaching (BEST)
Description: The Baccalaureate Education in Science and Teaching (BEST) Minor is designed to broaden STEM majors’ career opportunities by preparing them to teach high school science, mathematics, or computer science. The minor is offered for STEM majors at UNC Charlotte who desire to add high school licensure to their degree.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $5,000

ProgramName: Minor in Behavioral Sciences
Requirements: To declare this minor a student must have a GPA of at least 2.0.
Description: The Minor in Behavioral Science offers a single general concentration. This interdisciplinary minor allows students to apply the tools and concepts of multiple behavioral science disciplines, including psychology, sociology, anthropology, geography, political science, and economics, to analyze real-world problems. The coursework is designed to help students understand the many factors that influence individual, group, and organizational behavior, and develop critical thinking and communication skills through the study of diverse perspectives on human behavior. It complements a wide array of majors, providing students with a valuable credential and enhancing their ability to address complex issues in various professional settings, including health care, education, public policy, and business.

ProgramName: Minor in Biology
Requirements: Students can declare this minor by using the online program declaration system in Banner Self-Service. A grade of C or above is required in all courses for the minor.
Description: The minor in biology offers a valuable credential for students majoring in other sciences or in fields requiring a fundamental knowledge of biology. The minor is also open to students in other colleges. The minor requires a minimum of 18 semester hours with a minimum GPA of 2.0 in the minor and an overall GPA of 2.0 in courses applicable to the minor. A grade of C or better is required in each course counted toward the minor.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, special talent, or financial need

ProgramName: Minor in Bioinformatics
Department: College of Computing and Informatics and College of Liberal Arts & Sciences
Description: The Undergraduate Minor in Bioinformatics provides students with a foundational understanding of the principles, methodologies, and applications of bioinformatics. It is designed for students interested in the interdisciplinary field that combines biology, computer science, mathematics, and statistics to analyze and interpret biological data. Students pursuing this minor will gain expertise in computational tools and techniques used to manage, analyze, and visualize large biological datasets, such as genomic, proteomic, and transcriptomic data. The curriculum covers key areas including sequence alignment, phylogenetic analysis, gene expression analysis, and structural bioinformatics. This minor prepares students for careers or further studies in bioinformatics, computational biology, biotechnology, and related fields, equipping them with the necessary skills to address complex biological problems using computational approaches.

ProgramName: Minor in Business Administration
Requirements:
The Minor in Business Administration is available to students in all colleges at UNC Charlotte except the Belk College of Business. Students must meet all course prerequisites and have a minimum 2.5 overall GPA to be admitted to the minor. A minimum grade of C is required in each course in the minor.

The 18-credit hour minor requires the following courses:
ACCT 2121 Principles of Financial Accounting (3)
ECON 2101 Principles of Economics-Macro (3)
ECON 2102 Principles of Economics-Micro (3)
INFO 2130 Introduction to Business Computing (3)
MGMT 3140 Management and Organizational Behavior (3)
MKTG 3110 Principles of Marketing (3)

ProgramName: Minor in Chemistry
Description: A minor in Chemistry is designed for students who want to develop a fundamental understanding of chemistry, but who are not majoring in chemistry. This minor can complement a variety of majors in the College of Liberal Arts & Sciences, the College of Engineering, and the College of Health & Human Services, among others. Students will gain knowledge and skills in general, organic, and analytical chemistry, as well as an introduction to physical and inorganic chemistry concepts. The minor provides a strong foundation for students interested in careers requiring a basic understanding of chemical principles or for those considering graduate studies in interdisciplinary fields.

ProgramName: Minor in Chinese
Requirements: Students who want to declare a minor in Chinese should fill out the online form.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in Chinese introduces students to the Chinese language and culture through a series of language, culture, and literature courses. Students must complete at least 18 hours of coursework above the 1201 level, and must earn a grade of C or above in all courses used to satisfy the requirements of the minor.
CostPerCredit: In-State: $369.38, Out-of-State: $1,078.88 (Tuition & Fees per credit hour for 2023-2024)

ProgramName: Minor in Civic Life and Leadership
Minor in Classical Humanities
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: A Minor in Classical Studies complements almost any major and provides a strong foundation for future study in a variety of fields, including archaeology, art history, law, medicine, museum studies, and many others. Our Classical Studies program offers courses in Greek and Latin languages, Classical Literature (in translation), Greek and Roman history, archaeology, mythology, and art. Courses are taught by award-winning faculty with a wide range of expertise. A Classical Studies minor can broaden your knowledge and perspective in a variety of fields. Because Classical Studies focuses on close reading and analysis of texts, ancient authors, and historical contexts, students develop excellent critical thinking, communication, and problem-solving skills which are highly valued by employers. It is a particularly good foundation for further study in areas such as Law, Medicine, and Graduate studies in the Humanities.
ScholarshipAmount: $2,000 to full ride

ProgramName: Minor in Climate Change
Requirements: To declare a minor in Climate Change, students must have a GPA of at least 2.0. A minor in Climate Change requires 18 credit hours. All courses must be passed with a grade of C or better. At least half the credit hours must be taken at UNC Charlotte. Courses taken on a Pass/No Credit basis may not be used toward the minor. Students must take courses from three categories as listed below: Required Core Courses, Climate System, and Human Dimensions.
Fees: In-State: $12,002/year, Out-of-State: $42,442/year (based on 2023-2024 full-time undergraduate tuition and fees)
Description: The Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences offers a minor in Earth and Environmental Sciences for students who wish to supplement their major with knowledge about the Earth System (e.g., geology, meteorology, oceanography) and the environment (e.g., pollution, environmental impacts, and natural resources).

ProgramName: Minor in Coaching Education
Requirements: The minor in coaching education is an 18-credit hour minor offered by the Department of Kinesiology. The minor requires six (6) credit hours of required coursework, and 12 credit hours of elective coursework from an approved list of courses. A minimum GPA of 2.0 is required in the minor coursework. To declare the minor, students must have a 2.0 GPA, meet with the Minor Advisor, and complete the “Change/Add Major/Minor” form in Banner Self-Service.
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Fees: In-State: $7,490 per year; Out-of-State: $21,136 per year
Description: Students interested in coaching at any level benefit from Lasell's Minor in Coaching. Designed to complement any major, the Minor provides students with fundamental knowledge in sport psychology, injury prevention, strength and conditioning, and sport administration. Graduates are prepared to seek coaching positions in a variety of settings from youth sports to high school and collegiate sports. Students may also obtain national certification from the American Sport Education Program (ASEP).

ProgramName: Minor in Cognitive Science
Description:
Cognitive science is the interdisciplinary study of mind, brain, and intelligence. It explores how we perceive, think, remember, learn, make decisions, and use language. The Minor in Cognitive Science is designed to give students exposure to the theories and methodologies used by researchers in psychology, computer science, philosophy, and linguistics to study cognition, and to prepare them for advanced study and research in cognitive science.

The minor draws courses from Psychology, Computer Science, Philosophy, and Languages and Culture Studies. It requires a total of 18 credit hours, including nine hours of core courses and nine hours of elective courses. The elective courses must be selected from at least two different departments. A maximum of six credit hours can be counted toward both the student’s major and the minor. In addition, students must earn a minimum grade of “C” in all courses counted toward the minor.
